Maps between Morava E-theories

Mar 8, 2019

We ended the previous post by saying that for a fixed finite and , there is a -map between Morava -theories. We will discuss a construction of this map in this post. To define this map, let denote a formal -divisible group of height over a perfect field , and let denote the Lubin-Tate spectrum associated to the formal group . We will construct a -divisible group whose formal component has height over a perfect field , and an -ring map .

Algebraically, our desired map goes from to . There is a natural choice of for which such a map exists: let denote the direct limit perfection of the -algebra , i.e., the direct limit of the diagram

There is a naturally defined -divisible group over : it is the pullback of the universal deformation of the formal -divisible group along the map

which is the same as the map

Let denote the -divisible group over , so that there are morphisms of pairs . It is a consequence of Proposition 6.1.5 of Lurie’s Elliptic II, that there is an equivalence of oriented deformation -rings (thanks to Andy Senger for pointing this out to me). We conclude from the main theorem of loc. cit. (in particular, the functoriality) that there is a map of -rings .

At this point, we run into a slight issue: the formal component of is of height (the associated Morava -theory is of height ), and although there is a map of -rings, this map will not be an equivalence. (This is why we do not obtain a map between plain old Morava -theories, as mentioned in the first paragraph.) However, by Theorem 6.2.4 of loc. cit., the map between the unoriented deformation rings induced by the map is flat. Since the oriented deformation rings are even-periodic, and of the oriented deformation ring is isomorphic to of the unoriented deformation ring (the universal deformation is “balanced”), this implies that the map is flat as well. Moreover, since is the classical deformation ring of over , we find that the map of classical rings is just given by the map sending to . This map is faithfully flat, too, so the map of -rings is also faithfully flat. Corollary 3.33 from here is therefore applicable, and allows us to conclude that the map admits descent; in other words, is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial object . Concretely, this implies that smashing with is conservative on -modules, which in turn implies that the Bousfield class of agrees with that of .

We know that is a Morava -theory of height , so this tells us that -localization is equivalent to -localization, and that is the geometric realization of the cosimplicial object by the Hopkins-Ravenel smash product theorem. The map of -rings we constructed above therefore determines a map of cosimplicial -rings, and this induces the canonical map upon geometric realization. Since we can iterate the construction of the map , we obtain for our fixed , and any , a map of -rings from to another -ring such that the induced map on geometric realizations of the associated cosimplicial objects induces the canonical map . The discussion at the end of our previous post now implies that for any fixed , we can construct maps for all which are compatible with respect to the canonical maps of -rings for (in other words, the obvious diagram involving the maps and commutes). These maps depend a priori on the choice of formal group over , but I would not be surprised if different choices of height formal -divisible group gave rise to the same maps .

(Edit: I should’ve added the following statement. Since is a perfect field, the connected-etale sequence for splits. Because the deformation theory of etale group schemes is trivial, we obtain an -ring map ; this in turn gives an -ring map between Morava -theories of different heights.)

Note that all of this requires to be finite and fixed: our construction needs one to start off with a fixed formal -divisible group of height over a perfect field. In particular, we do not obtain a map . Perhaps such a map could be constructed if the phrase “Morava -theory at infinite height” could be made to make sense.
